pageData.text: Human genomic DNA is isolated and then observed in this lab activity. Using a simple procedure, cheek cells are collected from the student’s mouth and lysed to release the DNA into a solution. Chromosomal DNA is then precipitated out of solution using cold ethanol. The DNA strands are isolated and transferred to a clean microcentrifuge tube for observation.

pageData.text: Sitting Bull was a chief and medicine man of the Hunkpapa Lakota Sioux. He united and defended the Sioux tribes against invading settlers until his death in1890. Although Sitting Bull was originally buried in Fort Yates, ND, his remains were moved to Mobridge, SD in the 1950s; a group of businessmen hoped the gravesite would attract tourists. For years, Sitting Bull’s great-grandson, Ernie LaPointe, tried to return his ancestor’s remains to honorable ground. Then, in 2021, scientists developed a new method of DNA analysis that could confirm LaPointe’s relationship to Sitting Bull.Genetic genealogy investigations usually focus on sex-specific genetic comparisons. This is because the Y chromosome is only passed to male descendants and mitochondrial DNA is passed from mothers to children. But LaPointe is related to Sitting Bull on his mother’s side, rendering common sex-linked techniques useless. So, scientists developed a technique that allowed them to focus on autosomal DNA, or non-sex-specific DNA, which is inherited from both parents. LaPointe is hopeful that with genetic confirmation of the genealogical records kept by the Lakota Tribe he can finally bring his ancestor’s remains home1.1Chow, Denise. “Sitting Bull's Great-Grandson Identified through DNA Fragments.” NBCNews.com, NBCUniversal News Group, 28 Oct. 2021, https://www.nbcnews.com/science/science-news/sitting-bulls-great-grandson-identified-dna-fragments-rcna3912.

pageData.altText: Portrait of Sitting Bull.

pageData.subTitle: DNA Is the “Code of Life”
pageData.text: Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is the hereditary “code of life.” It possesses the information that determines an organism’s characteristics, and is transmitted from one generation to the next. The genetic code can be compared to a recipe or a list of instructions on how to create and maintain a specific organism. Almost all living organisms are dependent on and determined by DNA; the structure of DNA is consistent among all species, comprising of the four bases guanine (G), adenine (A), thymine (T), and cytosine (C).

Although the structure of DNA is conserved, <button class='glossary-text'>genes</button> differ between organisms. Genes are specific sequences of the bases G, A, T, and C; they occupy specific locations on chromosomes and control particular traits. This creates explicit “blueprints” for building individual organisms. Genes encode the information needed to synthesize proteins and determine the expression level, or abundance, of a protein. For example, our DNA controls the color of our skin, independent of environmental influences such as exposure to sunlight. Each human skin cell produces a specific amount of the protein pigment, melanin, according to the information encoded in the melanin gene. Inherited variations in this gene account for skin color variation in the human population.

pageData.subTitle: Packaging of DNA
pageData.text: DNA is contained within the nucleus of almost every cell in the human body (erythrocyte red blood cells being the only exception). The length of DNA in each cell is about 100,000 times that of the cell itself. However, DNA takes up only approximately 10% of the cell volume. This is because DNA is tightly packaged through a series of compaction events to fit easily within the cell nucleus (Figure 1). The basic structure of DNA is that of a twisted ladder, or double helix. In order to condense the molecule, the double helix wraps itself around groups of proteins called <button class='glossary-text'>histones</button>. Histones wrapped by DNA have the appearance of beads on a string. This DNA-histone complex is called <button class='glossary-text'>chromatin</button>, and the bead-like regions are called <button class='glossary-text'>nucleosomes</button>. The chromatin then folds back on itself, and the nucleosomes pack together to create a compact, protein-coated fiber. The fiber coils shorten further into an extended chromosome. In its most compressed state, this coiled fiber organizes into loops emanating from a central axis (scaffold) to create a condensed, X-shaped chromosome (Figure 1).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: DNA double helix creating a condensed, X-shaped chromosome.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: DNA double helix creating a condensed, X-shaped chromosome.

pageData.text: Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes in the nucleus of every cell, with the exception of eggs and sperm. If the 46 chromosomes from one human cell were unraveled and lined up end-to-end, they would measure approximately 6 feet. When cells are not dividing (in interphase), the chromosomes are extended and bunch together, filling the nucleus like a ball of cotton. During cell division () the chromosomes condense and become 46 distinct X-shaped structures ().

Chromosomal DNA from a single cell is not visible to the naked eye. However, when DNA is extracted from multiple cells, the amassed material can be easily seen and has the appearance of strands of mucus-like, translucent cotton. This DNA is coated with proteins and at various stages of condensation (Figure 1). Individual, condensed chromosomes can be observed using light microscopy, but the double helix is only nanometers wide and can be detected only using sophisticated imaging techniques, such as scanning probe microscopy.

DNA has a twisted ladder shape.

pageData.subTitle: DNA Extraction from Human Cheek Cells
pageData.text: In order to extract chromosomal DNA from the epithelial lining of the human cheek, or buccal mucosa, a sample of intact cells must first be collected. In this activity, a sports drink mix is used as a mouthwash and collection medium. This type of drink mixture contains salt (sodium chloride), and thereby constitutes saline solutions compatible with the osmotic environment of the cells. This means that the cells do not dramatically gain or lose volume during collection. If water were used as the collection medium, its <button class='glossary-text'>hypotonic</button> nature would cause the cells to take up water (by osmosis) and burst, or lyse. The saline nature of the sports drink mix prevents the cells from lysing and releasing their DNA before they are collected. This method of collection amasses a large quantity of cheek cells from which DNA is extracted.

Once the intact cells are collected, the membranes that surround the cells and their nuclei must be broken. These membranes act as barriers to protect and separate the cell, nucleus, and DNA from the surrounding environment. Cell and nuclear membranes are composed of two layers of phospholipids called a <button class='glossary-text'>phospholipid bilayer</button>. To lyse cells in a test tube, the cell and nuclear membranes are disrupted with a detergent-based lysis solution. Just as a dishwashing detergent dissolves fats (lipids) to clean a frying pan, a detergent-based cell lysis solution dissolves the phospholipid bilayer of cell membranes by forming water-soluble complexes with the lipids. Once the cell membranes have been disrupted, the cell contents flow out and create a “soup” of dissolved membranes, cellular proteins, DNA, and other molecules. This “soup” is called the <button class='glossary-text'>cell lysate</button>.

The DNA in the cell lysate is in solution. This means that it is incorporated in the liquid lysate and is not visible (like a teaspoon of sugar dissolved in a cup of water). However, DNA is insoluble in ethanol (an alcohol), meaning that it cannot be incorporated into the liquid (like a teaspoon of sand in a cup of water). Therefore, DNA from the cell lysate can be visualized by applying a layer of ethanol on top of the cell lysate.

When the ethanol comes in contact with the <button class='glossary-text'>cell lysate</button>, it causes the DNA to precipitate, or come out of solution, forming a translucent cloud of fine, stringy fibers at the ethanol-cell lysate interface. Cold ethanol precipitates DNA to the greatest extent. DNA is negatively charged due to the phosphate ions on its backbone. The salinity of the sports drink mix neutralizes this negative charge by coating the DNA with positively-charged sodium ions. This counteracts the mutual repulsion of the DNA strands and allows them to clump together as they precipitate.

It is important to remember that the extracted DNA from human cheek cells represents a huge collection of chromosomes (many strands of DNA) isolated from a large quantity of cells and clustered together. This DNA is folded and condensed around protein molecules and is considered crude because it has not been separated from the cellular proteins that adhere to it during precipitation.

pageData.subTitle: Importance of DNA Extraction
pageData.text: The principles of DNA extraction used in this activity apply to procedures used by scientists to extract DNA from a multitude of sources. DNA extraction is a fundamental procedure in scientific laboratories around the world and is often the first step in many in-depth laboratory experiments. By extracting and analyzing DNA, scientists can learn how DNA encodes the instructions for all life processes. DNA extraction and analysis is important in basic research, such as the investigation of the mechanisms underlying heredity, and in clinical science, such as the potential treatment of diseases through gene therapy. Extracted DNA can be used to create DNA fingerprints (Figure 2) to aid in the diagnosis of genetic disease, facilitate forensic analysis, identify victims of disaster and war, and establish paternity or maternity. Scientists can genetically engineer changes in DNA to create robust, disease-resistant, genetically modified plants and animals. DNA extraction is also necessary in order to sequence and compare the DNA codes, or genomes, of organisms (as in the Human Genome Project).

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Columns of bands representing DNA fingerprints on an electrophoresis gel.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Columns of bands representing DNA fingerprints on an electrophoresis gel.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting the activity, chill the ethanol and create a sports drink solution. In Activity 1, you will swish the sports drink solution in your mouth and col580106_Bio_ED_001lect the swished solution with cheek cells. Then, you will mix the cell lysis solution with the collected solution and layer cold ethanol on top of the solution. Allow the tube contents to incubate for 10 minutes, then pipet out the ethanol layer with the DNA precipitate. Finally, you will observe the extracted DNA.
pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting the activity, chill the ethanol and create a sports drink solution. In Activity 1, you will swish the sports drink solution in your mouth and collect the swished solution with cheek cells. Then, you will mix the cell lysis solution with the collected solution and layer cold ethanol on top of the solution. Allow the tube contents to incubate for 10 minutes, then pipet out the ethanol layer with the DNA precipitate. Finally, you will observe the extracted DNA.

add sports drink to the cell lysate, dying the DNA a bright pink

add sodium chloride to the cell lysate, breaking down the histones

typeBefore.text: Avoid coffee consumption a few hours before cheek cell collection. Coffee consumption greatly impedes the DNA extraction process.
Chill the 70% ethanol by storing it in a freezer or in a container of ice until ready for use in step 10 of the Procedure.

pageData.text: Read through Procedure.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize work area.

Prepare the sports drink by removing a little less than an ounce of water (which you can measure with the medicine cup) from the 16.9-ounce bottle. This will bring the amount of water in the bottle to approximately 16 ounces. Add the contents of the sports drink mix packet to the remaining 16 ounces of drinking water in the bottle.

If you cannot ingest the sports drink, you can use your own homemade sports drink alternative, or create a salt solution by adding 3 tablespoons of table salt to the bottle of water rather than the drink mix packet.
In this activity, you will use sports drink mix to slough off a sample of your own cheek cells from which you will extract and isolate their DNA.

pages.title: Cheek Cell DNA Extraction (19 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Cheek Cell DNA Extraction (19 steps)

pageData.text: Using the medicine cup, measure ~ 2.5 mL of prepared sports drink.

Pour the prepared sports drink from the medicine cup into your mouth (do not swallow) and swish it around for 1 full minute. While swishing the sports drink, gently and continuously scrape the insides of your cheeks with your teeth to help release the cheek cells.*
* This step is important to gently transfer cheek cells into the solution. Scraping the inside of your mouth will help loosen cells. More cells in solution means that more DNA will be extracted.
After 1 minute of swishing, gently spit the sports drink with the collected cheek cells back into the medicine cup.
Carefully pour the contents of the medicine cup into the 15-mL tube. Discard the cup.
Place the 15-mL tube upright in a plastic cup and let it stand undisturbed for 5 minutes.
After 5 minutes, hold the tube up to the light to better see the cells sinking to the bottom of the tube. Food debris may also be visible in the solution.
Add the contents of the cell lysis solution bottle to the collected cheek cells. This solution was premeasured for this laboratory activity.
Cap the 15-mL tube tightly and invert it 5 times (do not shake). This action mixes the cell lysis solution with the collected cheek cell sample.
Allow the tube to stand in the cup for 2 minutes.
Remove the ethanol from the freezer or ice container.
Remove the cap from the tube.

Hold the 15-mL tube at an angle, and using a plastic pipet, carefully add the cold ethanol by running it down the inside wall of the tube. Add the ethanol until the total volume inside the tube reaches 12–13 mL (use the lines on the side of the tube for measurement).

The exact amount of ethanol is not important. What is important is that the ethanol is carefully layered on top of the lysis solution. There should be two distinct layers. Do not mix the cheek <button class='glossary-text'>cell lysate</button> layer with the ethanol layer (Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 3: DNA becoming visible between the cheek cell lysate layer and the ethanol layer in the 15 mL capped plastic tubes.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: DNA becoming visible between the cheek cell lysate layer and the ethanol layer in the 15 mL capped plastic tubes.

pageData.text: Watch closely as wispy strands of translucent DNA begin to clump together where the ethanol layer meets the cell lysate layer (Figure 3).
The DNA will look like a cobweb extending up from the cell lysate layer. Tiny bubbles in the ethanol layer will appear where the DNA precipitates.
Place the 15-mL tube upright in the cup and let it stand undisturbed for a minimum of 10 minutes. Do not shake or disturb the tube. Take a photo of the DNA before proceeding to the next step.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: During this time, DNA will continue to precipitate out of solution and extend like a ribbon through the entire ethanol layer.
After 10 minutes have passed, obtain a clean disposable pipet and microcentrifuge tube in preparation for transferring the precipitated DNA out of the 15-mL tube.
Click here to view a video demonstrating how to work at the interface of layered liquids.

pageData.desc: Working at the Interface of Layered Liquids

pageData.text: Begin pipetting the DNA from the uppermost end of the most extended strand in the ethanol layer. The DNA should be drawn up as one strand. Do not move your pipet tip down into the cell lysate (red/pink) layer.

If some of the DNA remains attached to the cell lysate layer, draw the pipet up until the DNA in the pipet detaches from that in the cell lysate layer. All of the DNA does not have to be captured and transferred to the microcentrifuge tube.

Continue to hold the pipet over the 15-mL tube and allow the DNA to sink to the tip of the pipet. If the DNA does not sink, release ethanol dropwise back into the tube until the DNA moves down into the pipet tip.
Gently expel the DNA into the microcentrifuge tube and fill the tube dropwise with ethanol. Do not overfill the tube.
Observe and take a photo of the extracted DNA in the microcentrifuge tube (Figure 4).
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Extracted DNA in the microcentrifuge tube.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Extracted DNA in the microcentrifuge tube.

text: Pour the remaining sports drink, cell lysis buffer, and ethanol down the drain with excess tap water.
Discard used pipets and tubes in household trash.
Put all remaining supplies back in the lab box.
Clean your work area with a household surface cleaner.

data.title: Cell lysate
data.content: The mixture of dissolved membranes, cellular proteins, DNA, and other molecules that exude from cells with damaged plasma membranes

data.title: Chromatin
data.content: The complex of DNA and histones

data.title: Genes
data.content: The specific sequences of DNA found in specific locations on chromosomes and that control particular traits

data.title: Histones
data.content: The proteins that bind to DNA, and help give chromosomes their shape and control the activity of genes

data.title: Hypotonic
data.content: The solution with the lower solute concentration relative to another solution

data.title: Mitosis
data.content: The division of body cells that results in genetically identical cells

data.title: Nucleosomes
data.content: The bead-like regions of chromatin where DNA is wrapped around histones

data.title: Phospholipid bilayer
data.content: Two layers of phospholipids, which have environment-facing hydrophilic heads and inward-facing hydrophobic tails
